course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Convex Optimization
course.description: Convex optimization theory with applications to communication systems and signal processing: convex sets/functions/problems; Lagrange duality and KKT conditions; saddle points and minimax problems; numerical algorithms; primal/dual decomposition methods. Applications: filter design; robust beamforming; power control in wireless systems; design of MIMO systems; GP duality in information theory; network utility maximization. For PG students in second year or above.

reviews.author: Sergei
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers most parts of the book "Convex Optimization" by Stephen Boyd, Lieven Vandenberghe

The course content:

convex sets
convex functions
convex optimization problems
duality (significant time is devoted to the Lagrange duality, KKT conditions, Slater's conditions)
Applications in statistics (like parametric distribution estimation)
Applications to geometric problem
Convex optimization algorithms
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching was very dry, and it was simply rewriting part of the book to a whiteboard with very less instructor's insights.
reviews.comment_grading:
The home assignments are graded by a TA, very quickly and accurately.

The midterm and final exams were graded by the professor. Professors grading strategy was very nitpicky and tedious, for the exam with 50 pts max, the mean was about 14 pts.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very high. 5 assignments with ~13 exercises from the book per each, midterm, final and a project (which requires 5 pages report).

The most problems (both for the midterm and for the final) were drawn from the book. So solving the assignments during a semester is essential.

The final project requirements were extremely vague: we needed to "apply the learned theory to  important real life problem". No references examples or further explanations were given.

reviews.author: Amirhossein
reviews.comment_content: Very useful content with applications in different areas in signal processing, communications and even finance. Covers topics in convex problems and taxonomy (LP, QP, SOCP, SDP, GP), Lagrange duality and KKT conditions,  Algorithms primer (Newton, IPM, BCD), MM and SCA based algorithms and the applications in Filter design, Classification and SVM in machine learning, Sparse index tracking in finance and etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is excellent. Nice instructor with good teaching skills and a sense of humor.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fine. There course has at least 3 A+ grades.
reviews.comment_workload: The course has a final project which takes some workload to do. There are also a midterm exam and 4 assignments.

reviews.author: dennnnis
reviews.title: Quite math intensive
reviews.comment_content: The course contains much information on Convex optimization, which is math intensive, and hard to grasp. Also, since too many contents are invloved, usually the pace is too fast. Another cons is the lecture is at evening, with 3 hours and 1 break, it is easy for you too go nowhere at last half of the lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although there are bad comments on  contents, the instructor deserves a good one. The instructor tries his best to make the course funny, and lots of life philosophy is brought about in the middle of the class.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grade, but take hard effort to gain. Its easy to stay pass, but hard to get excellent.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 hw question set with few programming in python, r or matlab
1 midterm
1 final proj in team (with presentation and written report)

reviews.author: R.Fisher
reviews.comment_content: This course is application oriented. It covers a wide range of practical examples where convex optimization can be applied. The requirement for math is of middle level. Basic concepts of convex optimization are introduced with intuitive examples. The course content could be very useful in applied Science. Some basic skills in analysis are required.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Daniel is interesting and passionate. He is good at providing intuition for complicated math concepts and tries to avoid tedious math in the instruction.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite fair, largely depends on the course project. A midterm is required for passing the course. One can generally get a satisfied grade if the assignments and project are well finished.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite hard, especially for the project. The homework is of middle harness. One should pay about two days to finish a homework.

reviews.author: genta.winata
reviews.comment_content: The course is relatively difficult and you need to know linear algebra and calculus. You must review the course every week to catch up with the content. Don't need to afraid, you will learn a lot of new things!
reviews.comment_teaching: Very fast. Interesting. You will not be bored in the class. Most of the time, he skipped many slides, but always stop when explaining important concept.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. Exam is open book, but don't expect you can finish it without preparation
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not pretty tough. Homeworks are very challenging and time consuming. No final, only mid term. Project depends on you. Very flexible
